One of the most overrated anime in the century. I understand that the manga could appeal to a lot of people but frankly, the anime was really bad. I have counted in total 223 filler episodes on 500. Don't you think that almost half of the episodes of the anime is way too much? Moreover, 90% of these filler were not interesting at all. I know that they put it there so the anime doesn't catch up to the manga but it was way too unsatisfying. It is because of these filler that I dropped the anime for a long time. The art was not bad, I mean some jutsu were kind of original and pretty. The OST/Openings were good too. If they had just put the manga stuff, I would probably rate it with 8/9 but the way they handled the anime was bad. NB: The characters were not really interesting, some characters were really likeable like Jiraya, Minato, Naruto, Shikamaru,... but on all the characters(those that we know the name at least) I was able to like only 5-8%. NB+: How come Shippuuden has a better grade than the first series. I think the first one is way better.

Look, I get saying the filler brings it down if you watched the show as it aired; however, I am blessed with watching it after the airing has completed. I skip all segments of filler and only watch ones that a well-liked. I think if the show is watched as I am watching it now, it is the single best anime ever created. It has fantastically deep and dimensional characters, the fights (while I see why others think differently) look gorgeous, and lastly, it truly puts the time into forming the plot and doesn't feel rushed. Lastly, I feel its incorrect top judge Naruto and Shippuuden separately, if watched in a single stretch the events of Shippuuden feel perfectly written and well played out.

With how much love Naruto Shippuden gets—aside from maybe its final arc—I'm personally surprised the time skip (or Shippuden, as the anime calls it) isn’t criticized more for its actual issues. I’m not talking about the anime’s slow pacing and filler—that’s been talked about to death. I mean problems that were in the manga itself and just carried over into the anime. That said, I should be fair and explain my perspective—why I was disappointed, but also what I did like about Shippuden. In general, I prefer pre-time skip Naruto. Not only was the cast decently sized without feeling bloated, but the tone had a good mix of lightheartedness, magic, and actual strategy. However, due to the events of the Sasuke Retrieval Arc, it’s understandable that Shippuden lost much of its whimsical charm. Even the soundtrack feels more serious and somber. That’s one thing Shippuden does well—consistently emphasizing tragedy. And, oh boy, there’s a lot of it. While pre-time skip Naruto fumbled with who the real villains were from arc to arc, Shippuden at least has solid villain buildup. Almost every major conflict connects to a larger antagonist, which helps the story feel more cohesive. I also think Naruto (the character) himself improved. Pre-time skip Naruto had some nice moments but was generally a bit too annoying for me. Post-time skip, he’s more tolerable and has more memorable moments, though he can still be frustrating and occasionally bland. And while there aren’t as many as I’d like, Shippuden does have some great emotional moments. Some are tied to backstories, but a few present-day scenes stand out and keep things memorable. Unfortunately, that’s about where my positives end. One of my favorite things about pre-time skip Naruto was its balance of magic (ninjutsu) and strategy. Unfortunately, Shippuden gradually reduces the importance of ninja tactics, making fights feel like they’re decided purely by who has the strongest jutsu. Strategy occasionally appears, but it’s subtle—sometimes too subtle. This made many action scenes duller than they should have been. Sure, there are some cool set pieces and hard-hitting moments, but when everyone is just spamming super-powerful ninjutsu, and things like shuriken, bombs, and taijutsu barely matter (outside of that one insane Might Guy moment), it really shows how much power creep affected the fights. Even in pre-time skip Naruto, some characters were already being pushed to the background despite having cool designs or moments. Shippuden takes this issue and dials it up to 100. So many characters we got to emotionally connect with—or at least see do something cool—get shafted. Asuma, Kurenai, Choji, Shino, Anko, Rock Lee, Neji, Tenten—the list goes on. These were characters we got to know as early as the second arc, yet in Shippuden, they barely do anything. The only exceptions are a few obvious fan favorites like Shikamaru, Gaara, and I guess Hinata—but that’s about it. You’d think the Fourth Great Ninja War Arc would be the perfect time to make all these characters relevant again, and the series tried, but in my opinion, it fumbled hard. Why? Because there were too many characters introduced on top of an already large cast. Not only do we still have all the Leaf Village ninjas, but now we also have other village ninja, Kages, Tailed Beast hosts, Sasuke’s new Hebi allies, and temporary replacements for Sasuke and Kakashi in Team 7. With so many characters, most of them don’t get enough development to make us care about them beyond their base personality and powers. And sadly, that applies to the villains too. I do appreciate that the Akatsuki serve as Shippuden’s main antagonists. There was strong buildup for who should have been the final villain. But then there’s Kaguya. Without getting into spoilers, the lack of buildup for her is one of the most universally criticized aspects of Shippuden. There’s a bunch of nonsense about fate and reincarnation, and at this point, the ninja world’s reliance on magic becomes obnoxious. But honestly, Kaguya is just a symptom of a larger problem—Shippuden’s escalating power creep, which had been growing worse long before she even appeared. What’s probably the most disappointing for me is how Shippuden handled Team 7—the core reason the time skip even happened. By the end of pre-time skip Naruto, Sasuke’s character was already heading down a dark path. And let’s just say he becomes a lot more unlikable post-time skip. While there are good reasons for his descent, and some of it is due to certain characters withholding information from him, he still comes across as a moody, irrational mess. He constantly shifts his motives, becomes increasingly cruel, and gets way too much forgiveness for the terrible things he does. Then there’s Naruto and Sakura. They make so many dumb choices in their quest to “bring back" Sasuke. I get that this is the heart of the story, but the way it plays out is exhausting. Watching Naruto and Sakura regress personality-wise just to make this happen was frustrating, and by the end, I didn’t even find their resolution satisfying. Their dynamic, which should have been a highlight of Shippuden, ended up being one of its biggest headaches. I honestly feel bad for Kakashi—he had to deal with a bunch of emotionally unstable teenagers who eventually gained god-like powers and affected the world because of some melodramatic love-friendship nonsense. Shippuden has its moments—a stronger, more somber tone, some cool fights, and a handful of emotional scenes. But the things it focused on just weren’t for me. The bloated cast, the increasingly dull fights, and the Team 7 drama made it a slog. And the slow pacing certainly didn’t help. I wish I could have enjoyed it more, but we got what we got.

Review 20: Naruto Shippuden (Our favourite hero grew up?)??? Well, well, well he's returned to our screens once again. But did he mature??? No Is he smarter??? No Did his brightly coloured strange outfit change at all??? NO Another fun loving Anime program following on from the original Naruto series. We see our favourite hero returning after 2 years training with his sensei. He's still loud and annoying, but for once everyones happy to see the demon child that is Naruto. Unfortunetly for his long time freinds he still poses that pervy, hot naked chick move which still freaks me out on a mild level. Well Sakuras still the same to!!! Apart from the fact she's turned into a mini Tsunade, once again creepy on a mild level. Turns out in the years Naruto was training he became a great healer just like Tsunade.We see in the early episodes of Naruto Shippuden that even Tsunade's training may not be enough for some forms of healing. Her appearence has changed ever so slightly,the clothes follow the same colour scheme and fashion from the previous episodes, but I thought she would start growing her hair again for Sasuke, but it seems the shorter look has stayed and will be there to stay for a while. Apart from this she's literally the same person, a few slight alterations inher wardrobe have not altered the fact that whenever Naruto goes off of task... She's there to hit him. (Obviously)... With enhanced graphics and a slightly older audience to watch this series of Naruto it seems perfectly normal to me to jump straight in like they have. You know, introducing new characters and meeting up with past members of the Naruto series. I have to say, I did start to watch the original Naruto series but became bored as i'd already read it. So I thought to fit back into the crowd I would start watching the series again. Good decsion for once. I do think this series is better than the original. I think the only reason I think its better is because, well they've grown up, so its as if people my age can relate to the characters that we love. It may seem weird but it is true. I know younger kids at my school who prefer the first series to Naruto Shippuden as they can relate to him and the situations he's in. I don't think Naruto's personality has matured or grown up with him. I think its the appearence and the voice that make him seem older. I actually like this element of Naruto as I prefer his characters to be this way, the series wouldn't be the same if he was smart and sophisticated 24/7. I'm glad with te decsion to keep him as a wacky nut job instead of a stuck up tight wod. I prefer the aged Naruto to the younger one who always wanged to become hokage. Therefore I prefer Naruto Shippuden to the original Naruto series. (Sorry to offend anyone)... Sunday 10th Febuary 2013. 8:39 pm. ~AmyXxx

Settle in it's going to be a long ride. I know that doesn't seem like much to say about this show but it really will be a long show. Not only that each episode takes like eight years to do anything. So watch the show in clumps if you get a chance.

You'll probably read a lot of reviews, good and bad, about Naruto Shippuden. Personally, I was glad that the old Naruto ended and we had a time skip to when they are teenagers (not that I didn't enjoy some aspects of the old one but that's a whole other review). Story: I like that they all have grown up a bit. You can tell some thought has been put into their characters now. Even Sakura (cringe) has developed characteristically some. Naruto isn't *totally* a blubbering idiot. After awhile it just gets annoying to see everyone whining and acting like the elementary kids they are modeled to be. The story has some darkness to it now. The Akatsuki are rampaging across the Ninja Lands. Everyone is forced to fight. I mean, it's becoming a more adult(ish) anime while still preserving funny parts. Of course, we'd love to skip the fillers if we could, but truthfully, a lot of my favorite episodes have been fillers. I think most of them (not all) are beneficial to developing the characters and, let's face it, it's just that many more episodes to look back on after Naruto is over for good. Art: I rated this a 7 because they can really change from awesome to... (well see certain scenes of the Pain arc). It just seems sometimes the "good" artists took a sick day or something when some episodes are being done. Sound: I love just about all of the opening and closing songs. They are usually fitting choices with the feel they seem to be going for at the time. Also, their sounds effects are average enough to not seem to noticeably out of place. The songs they use in the episodes are okay, it's just that they've used most of the same ones since the beginning of Naruto and, frankly, I'm getting tired of the recycling. I think the fans are worth looking up a few more pieces of music... Also, sometimes they play their "epic" song (I don't know these names I just know that they play this when Naruto starts to get hyped up about something) at random times. It usually causes a good laugh. Character: As I said before, I really like that things seem to be growing up more than before. It's hard to describe without spoilers, but it just seems to mature which is great. Enjoyment: I eagerly sign on every Thursday to check out the newest episode and watch it on the spot whether its a filler or not. I enjoy the show and I'll probably be following to the very end. Overall it's an 8 for me. It would be higher, but for the sheer mass of fillers, random sound issues, and sloppy artwork from time to time. I would like to add one last thing, though: I can deal with the fillers, but the thing that makes me want to punch my computer screen is the flashbacks. Flashbacks every four seconds usually. There was one recent episode (at the Summit) that was one giant flashback recapping ALL of the episodes including the original Naruto. My. God. I understand that we need some from time to time to refresh our memories, but it got to the point that I could start reciting parts of scenes because of the flashbacks. Biggest downside: flashbacks. Anyways, I'd still recommend this anime to anyone who asked. I think it's dumb not to give it a try just because it's popular. It's just as stupid to NOT do something because it's popular than to do it because it is.

Naruto is a good show,but when it comes to Saske and Sakura it sucks.She is willing to die for him when he is trying to kill her.Every time that happens Naruto comes to the rescue.Sakura hates Naruto's guts.I believe Naruto is actually going to die if this keeps up.Like in that episode when Saske leaves her under water and Naruto comes to save her.Anyway after reading this you should look into this to see how he is sacrafising her.Please leave good comments and send friend requests.Thanks and good bye hope you liked it.

Undoubtedly the best shounen anime of all time (maybe bar one piece), and the long running show with the biggest fanbase is just a testament to how popular and good this series is. Naruto was my first anime (not counting pokemon) and still easily my favourite.I started this anime when i was a brat and watched another brat grow to the Hogake he's now. Everythings so awesome about naruto, that its hard to pick something and i have a very personal emotional attachment to naruto. With a vast world filled with jutsus and various techniques with awesome and unique character design for each character, breath taking fights where ur screaming and ur blood's boiling till it bursts, the moments that render u speechless, just the right amount of deaths (not too less or not to overdone like cough 'Akame ga kill'). and Naruto's character development is through the roof. This anime undoubtedly has the best villains overall, and the best villain anyways, with a backstories that make u sympathize with even Pain, who killed literally so many peeps (R.I.P. Pervy sage) and not to mention the most badass character ever, yes who else but the legendary Madara Uchiha. And the Kakashi Vs Obito, Madara Vs Guy, Naruto Vs Sasuke, every fight in Naruto has so much weight behind it, so much emotions behind them. The choreography is god tier. Naruto really set my bar for anime along with my bar for villains. The final showdown btw Naruto and Sasuke was very satisfying and exactly how a final fight's supposed to go down. There's still so much more i want to tell about Naruto but if this gets any bigger no one's gone read it. All i have left to say that this is the most ideal anime to start watching anime with.

Everyone, regardless if one is an anime viewer or not, will know Naruto. It had been the highlight of Anime Industry for years now. It is known for the story and actually created a craze for anime in a lot of people, including me. But Shippuuden is rather plagued with Fillers. Story: 7 Kishimoto has done an amazing job, creating a story while taking enough time to develop characters. The story has its twists and turns and is able to grip you into it. There are a few inconsistency in the timeline, especially Itachi and Kakashi, mostly because these characters were over developed. Art: 5 The art is good but the quality of the animation depends heavily on the studio. It can go from hand drawn like lazy animation to the best 2D animations. The low score is especially because of lack of quality in fillers. Sound: 8 Intense and gripping. Character: 8 Well developed. Kishimoto has again, outdone himself in creating his characters. Each character grown in his own accord though secondary characters are quite just their parents replica and i expect it to be the same in Boruto, Enjoyment: 8 I have loved Naruto for more than half a decade now I can't give an uniased opinion unless it is about the fillers. Overall: 7

i loved the series as a whole the characters had good development but some really wierd moments where they just say fuck it this guy is good now while he´s been the bad guy for 3 seasons but it was great and i had a lot of fun with it i watched till episode 393 and ended up dropping it because when you,ve been waiting for a long time throw a bat twist on the series and end a battle with a cliffhanger and follow up with a bunch of filler i,ve had enough ep 0-300 was great but after that it started to annoy me i stopped watching so i wouldnt ruin the show for myself cause in my eyes it just bought a plane ticket on the german airline that crashed yesterday

The obvious complaint is probably clear for anyone who has seen the show: filler. Good lord, there is a lot. At first I was fine with it, because it was the first anime I watched, and I watched a lot. Before I found Crunchyroll, I would google _________ vs _________ and watch the fight scenes, which would be 90 minutes long and 20 minutes of actual combat. But again, I was fine with that, even when I started to watch the series in order. Then I branched out to other anime that I saw on tumblr: Attack on Titan, Fairy Tail, and KnK to name a few. I was FLOORED the first time I watched AoT because of how much story they crammed into each episode. One episode of AoT was equal to seven episodes of Naruto. It's not even for story purposes; half of the Naruto filler is people glaring angrily at each other from across the battlefield. Plus, do you really want to watch seven episodes of the main character trying to rip a leaf for training? Another thing that I was not a fan of in Naruto was the amount of dues ex machinima they used during the battles. Just when a character seemed totally screwed, he would suddenly unveil a secret Jutsu that he/she cast twenty minutes before. It was like the writers put themselves in a corner every battle and had to create a miracle to save the plot. The soundtrack is amazing though, and it can give one goosebumps. The art is good, with sweeping landscaped and the collateral damage from the battles would show, which I thought showed a good attention to detail. Some characters you'll hate, others you'll love, and that's a good thing. The character development is nice, although the pacing can be shotty sometimes, and characters may disappear for weeks in-show. While this is a cornerstone in the anime world, and I do enjoy it a lot and would recommend it, I have to say there are substantially better animes out there. One good thing is that this show is not terribly far behind the manga, but that also is the cause of all the filler. Maybe, if this series was 150 episodes instead of 345 (as of this review), which would've been very doable, I would give this a 10.

Growing up with it , all i can say is that all the 90`s kids should agree with me that Naruto is one of the greatest anime ever made ! So i ain`t got so much to say about it ! The openings and the endings are amazing, u just can`t skip them ! The story is enjoyable ! The characters and the art are great as well ! (spoiler) Naruto is that kind of main character that is weak at the beginning, but at the end becomes the strongest ( love him ) ! Sadness happiness anger, all of those feelings u will meet through Naruto, sometimes they let me speechless ( just happened the impossible ) ! could not ask for a better show ! u all should watch it !

So this is not going to be a long review. Naruto is one of the most beloved manga, and it is noy hard to understand why. The setting is unique and the characters are very intresting. But in Shippuden all the elements that made part 1 unique are lost after a certain point. The fillers are too many making about 40 % of the series and the final arc is boring and full of plotholes. Now it might have stumbed a bit in the final arc but the ending is where it truly failed. Extremely important plotpoints are left unresolved and brushed aside and the characters lose their essence. It basically feels like you are watching strangers, which can be painful especially if you have come to love the characters and mainly the protagonist Naruto Uzumaki who loses all of the qualities that made him lovable among the audiences.

strong points + best thing about naruto has got to be the characters. naruto, itachi, jiraiya, these are just some of the few examples of profoundly impactful characters that have etched a deep impression onto its viewers and caused viewers to be extremely emotionally attached to them and whatever they may experience throughout the story + although not particularly sophisticated and intellectual to the likes of Death Note and Code Geass, naruto's story and universe in general are still very comprehensive and feel very immersive for the viewer + the use of music is very focused and adds heavily onto the atmosphere as and when appropriate, changing the mood and tone as it goes along. + many of the fight scenes that happen are very well thought out where characters do interesting things to try to outsmart their opponents or work together effectively to form a better strategy, generally applies for most fights weak points - of course the major criticism naruto gets is the insane amount of filler material/flashbacks present (almost 40% of the 500 episodes) and while this definitely prevents naruto from being a straight 9/10 due to the repetitiveness and loss of impact from overusing fillers, there is a filler guide available people use it as necessary - naturally, naruto's art and animations are not particularly the best. some character's faces and fight scenes in general are poorly animated (e.g. naruto vs pain) although generally they are good enough to go buy most of the time. don't expect anything close to violet evergarden or anything like that - naruto's pacing can be questionable at times, although this applies more exclusively for earlier seasons. from less important events being explored heavily to extremely draggy fight scenes, these are some of the issues with pacing. once again however, not a very big issue for the most part of naruto especially if you follow the filler guide at the end of the day, naruto is still one of the best big-ticket mainstream animes out there with a really comprehensive universe and some of the most impactful characters out there.

The screenplay/characters are attractive, and the seriousness is modern. Due to the influence of the setting, the world view is lacking, but the digging into the inner world is wonderful. In Japan, I feel that it is underestimated, probably because of the influence of the media. I finished watching 500 episodes in a month. There are two tricks to see. 1. Basically, I don't watch anime original episodes (personally, I only watch the past episodes 176-196 and Konoha Hiden from episode 494.) 2. Since the target age is wide, watch at the speed that suits you (I watched it at about 3x speed).

this Verse is threatned the Vengeance of God on the wicked unbelieving Israelites, that were God’s visible People, and lived under Means of Grace; and that, notwithstanding all God’s wonderful Works that he had wrought towards that People, yet remained, as is expressed, ver. 28. void of Counsel, having no Understanding in them; and that, under all the Cultivations of Heaven, brought forth bitter and poisonous Fruit; as in the two Verses next preceeding the Text. The Expression that I have chosen for my Text, Their Foot shall slide in due Time; seems to imply the following Things, relating to the Punishment and Destruction that these wicked Israelites were exposed to. 4 Sinners in the Hands 1. That they were always exposed to Destruction, as one that stands or walks in slippery Places is always exposed to fall. This is implied in the Manner of their Destruction’s coming upon them, being represented by their Foot’s sliding. The same is express’d, Psal. 73. 18. Surely thou didst set them in slippery Places; thou castedst them down into Destruction. 2. It implies that they were always exposed to sudden unexpected Destruction. As he that walks in slippery Places is every Moment liable to fall; he can’t foresee one Moment whether he shall stand or fall the next; and when he does fall, he falls at once, without Warning. Which is also expressed in that, Psal. 73. 18, 19. Surely thou didst set them in slippery Places; thou castedst them down into Destruction. How are they brought into Desolation as in a Moment? 3. Another Thing implied is that they are liable to fall of themselves, without being thrown down by the Hand of another. As he that stands or walks on slippery Ground, needs nothing but his own Weight to throw him down. 4. That the Reason why they are not fallen already, and don’t fall now, is only that God’s appointed Time is not come. For it is said, that when that due Time, or appointed Time comes, their Foot shall slide. Then they shall be left to fall as they are inclined by their own Weight. God won’t hold them up in these slippery Places any longer, but will let them go; and then, at that very Instant, they shall fall into Destruction; as he that stands in such slippery declining Ground on the Edge of a Pit that he can’t stand alone, when he is let go he immediately falls and is lost. The Observation from the Words that I would now insist upon is this, of an angry G O D. 5 There is nothing that keeps wicked Men at any one Moment, out of Hell, but the meer Pleasure of GOD.

I've finally finished Shippuden. I don't use the word finally to suggest the show was a drag, yes, it had it's up and downs, rather stratospheric up's and mind numbing downs to be frank, but on the whole it was an exciting, riveting, wholesome and heartbreaking experience I am very glad I finally got round to watching. I'm here not really sure what to write. So much has been written about Shippuden that this review won't really add anything to the thousands of reviews that have come before but nevertheless, here we go. I normally break up my reviews into 3 key parts; Story, Animation and music though I'm not sure that would really do this 500 ep show the justice it deserves so I'll separate the story into some of the key character's stories instead. Firstly, Ill cover the animation. Its really hard to say anything bad about the animation here. Naruto doesn't really lend itself to the over the top animated fight sequences compared to other shounen, simply because of how the characters fight and the usage of Ninjutsu. There were many times I was begging for some over the top moments but I can now safely say, when appreciated without my expectations, at worst the animation does exactly what it needs to, at best it's beautiful. Where the animation shines is in the hand to hand combat. I can't name specific fights here as it would have result in spoilers but it is safe to say they are stunning to watch. Don't get me wrong, there are some Ninjutsu based fights that are equally stunning, but I think it's safe to say that the fights in Shippuden have animation take a back seat to narrative, and what a narrative it is, I'll come to that later though. All in all, as I said above, at worst, the animation does exactly what is required of it and I wouldn't want it to change. I don't believe the animation needed to be more intense or mind-blowing, despite it not being either of these two things, I believe it is perfect for the show I would give it a 9/10. Moving on to the music. Personally, it's perfect. 10/10. The choices is music fit literally everything perfectly. Moments of stress building are have their own motif, moments of heartbreak have their own motif, moments of joy have their own motif and moments of saying goodbye the same. In between these recurring themes are subtle background sounds that deliver a true score experience. Some of the key standouts from the music are; Sadness and Sorrow, Martyr, Loneliness and my goodness, Experienced Many Battles borrows to my soul. Ill be honest, Ive named some here, but there are all perfect. I know the show is fresh in my mind, but with every passing second of these songs, I can hear vividly the characters, I can see the moments and if you take a look of the comments on YouTube to any of these songs you will see endless comparable remarks like mine. The music is not only stunning, but it has a way of replaying the moments in your mind with such vivid quality and floods your entire body with the accompanying emotions Shippuden delivers so beautifully. I watched this show when it was long finished, and it already resides within me emotionally, so much so that the smallest note can bring up the wonder of parts of this show. I can only imagine the connection and deep love people who watched this being released must feel for this show. I can imagine the music simultaneously breaks, repairs and embraces their hearts all at the same time. The music of Naruto is phenomenal. If you have finished the show and disagree, go here -https://youtu.be/kgaUXbOdbck?si=2330Rq_kUibM4fSF. I would put money on it that you change your mind very quickly. Its not until you hear the music outside of the show that it really hits you and you truly realise it's a masterpiece of an OST. Now I've got myself all emotional, what better thing is their to talk about next other than the characters and story.....here we go.....One thing this show does unbelievably well is emotion. It is within every single second. Whether that be love, sadness, forgiveness, anger, every emotion is perfectly conveyed. I would also like to point out that everything up to episodes around the 400 mark are 10/10. I found that within the episodes of 400 to 500, it's full of flashbacks, some you have seen multiple times by this point and it really starts to drag a little bit. So with this in mind, Shippuden is not a perfect show, but I would still give it a 9/10. Considering how many episodes there are, this is an incredible feat. Above, is the only real negative thing I have to say about the story really, so with that in mind I want to mention some characters. Jiraiya - for me, Jiraiya is everything to this anime. He is the rock for Naruto, he provides the perfect level of comic relief at time and ultimately in integral to most of the story's progression. Jiraiya plays such a fundamental role to this show that there is very little I can say here without spoiling something. There is so much I would want to say about this guy. One thing I will say is that Jiraiya will give you some of the best character driven arcs of any anime. He is in one of the best of Shippuden (The Tale of Jiraiya the Gallant) and is the undying flame behind possibly the greatest story arc ever written (Pain's Assault). Jiraiya is one of my favourite characters in this show and will likely be yours. Itachi - Speaking of the two arcs above, smack bang in the middle of them is Fated Battle Between Brothers. One thing is for certain, I can say absolutely nothing about this. Only that this changes everything. Itachi is such a superb antagonist. His mere appearance causes fear for anyone in his presence. He really is a fascinating character. Sadly however, I can say no more about him specifically. What I can say is there are some truly beautiful moments with Itachi involved and equally moments of excitement. He is involved in one of the greatest fights of the entire show and he deserves it. Sasuke - now, I can't say I have the same fondness for Sasuke as I do for the first two mentioned. I believe that he is a missed opportunity in this show. His character delivers very little for me. The only thing positive Sasuke adds is the fact that Naruto wants to bring him back to the Leaf. That's it for me. Most of the arcs he is part of are either rather boring or his part in the exciting arcs is boring. Also, he's just an unlikely character and I don't think it's down to purposeful writing. Good writing of an unlikely characters makes you enjoy not liking someone. Sasuke for me, is just unlikable and most of the time when he appears on screen, I want it to be over sooner rather than later. Pain - Ok, setting Sasuke to one side who is the only character is don't like, I'll talk about the perfect antagonist that is Pain. There is nothing about pain that is badly written. Every flashback, every line, every movement is perfect and yes, he is the key antagonist in Pain's Assault arc and what an arc it is. Most of you time you are just sat, mouth open in shock, or eyes flooded with tears through sadness or happiness. The characters writing of Pain is the best the show has, and this show has so many great characters I won't talk about. Pain is perfection and truly encapsulates the word itself. Again, I won't go into the content of the arc itself as it is so important not to know a thing going into this show but trust me, Pain and this arc is a masterpiece. Naruto - finally Naruto. Its really hard to put into words the journey this fool takes you on. I have laughed out loud, I have cried out loud, I have been heartbroken, warmed to the soul and been happy to continue with his every step of the way. Most characters develop over time, the character development in the show is superb, Naruto has it all from the beginning. Difference with Naruto is one layer of emotion is shown at certain times and covered back up when required. As far as protagonists go, he's is up their with Luffy. I'm sure there will be some One Piece elitists that disagree but his is and that's the end of it. The twists and turns Naruto has to go through is honestly and incredible ride and he also has the most emotional moments of the show, and they really are emotional. He is superb All in all this show is superb. All in all it's a very strong 9/10 for me. As I said at the top, 9/10 for a show with 500 episodes is quite the achievement. Shippuden is a must watch as far as I am concerned, a show with little flaws and moments that you will remember for the rest of your life.

Naruto Classic is good, and Shippuden starts well and remains acceptable until Pain's arc, after that it's just downhill. from there, Shippuden takes everything that was presented in the classic and throws it in the trash, remember the charismatic characters of the classic? forget everything, what matters here is only Naruto and Sasuke. Remember that Naruto story that "there is no destiny" and that "he makes his own destiny"? Forget it, Naruto is now the child of Ashura's prophecy and reincarnation. The Arc of War is one of the worst things ever done, too much trouble, screen time for characters that didn't matter at all for that part of the story, and LOTS of filler during the war, and if that weren't enough, there are even flashbacks in all episodes, a problem that has been around since classic Naruto. The animation worsens with each episode and the end of the war, come on, the final villain is an ALIENIGINE without any development that emerged FROM NOTHING in history and was defeated by a JUTSU HARÉM. Anyway, very bad, it's just not a complete crap, because it has Pain's arc which is good. I do not recommend

Naruto Shippuden is one of the most overrated anime I've seen. While it has a massive fanbase and a few unforgettable moments, the overall quality—especially the story—is weak at best. Let’s get this straight: the story is a mess. After the Pain arc and some decent world-building, it completely collapses. The war arc is bloated, filled with recycled flashbacks and dragged-out fights. The final Naruto vs Sasuke fight, which should’ve been the emotional climax of the entire series, felt lazy, forced, and anticlimactic. It had none of the depth it promised. I’d give the story a 1/10—purely because it had potential that it never delivered on. Now about the main character: Naruto himself is one of the most underwhelming protagonists in anime history. His entire character gets reduced to “talk no jutsu” and blind optimism. He rarely shows depth, complexity, or real emotional growth after a certain point. Ironically, his best fight probably isn’t even in this anime—it's in Boruto, where we finally see a more grounded, matured version of him. Despite all that, the character writing isn't completely hopeless. Shikamaru, Itachi, Jiraia and Kakashi are easily some of the best-written characters in anime, period. Their backstories, motivations, and emotional arcs are incredibly well done. Honestly, they carried the show. If the whole anime was written with their level of depth, Naruto Shippuden could’ve been on a completely different level. Animation is hit or miss. Some major fights look amazing, like Pain vs Naruto or Kakashi vs Obito, but outside of those, a lot of the animation looks dated or just plain bad in slower episodes. So I’d give it a 7/10, considering the time it aired. One major issue: filler. There’s way too much. Over 200 episodes of pure filler or poorly timed flashbacks completely ruin the pacing. Nothing kills hype like being thrown into a 5-episode childhood recap during a war. Final thoughts: A few legendary characters and fights aren’t enough to save Naruto Shippuden from weak storytelling, a bland main character, and a pacing disaster. Watch it for the highlights, skip the rest. Ratings: Story: 1/10 Animation: 4/10 Character Development (Naruto, Sasuke, Sakura): 4/10 Character Development (Itachi, Shikamaru, Kakashi etc.): 10/10 Character Build-up Overall: 7/10 Soundtrack: 8/10 Enjoyment: 4/10 Overall: 4.5/10

Naruto is for anime what Taylor Swift is for pop music: it divides opinions, definitely overrated in some aspects but it's something you should check if this is your thing. Naruto, despite its plot holes and misconstructed characters, is a story that's both too big to just end but too unique to have a satisfatory sequel. I'll forever keep it in my heart along with the strong feelings I had while watching. You'll watch someone's growth and I'm sure it will inspire you in some way, no matter where you are in life. I say this because I've been a fan for more than a decade and, although the things I like about the series and how I like them have changed, it's still very dear to me. I really reccomend watching it fully. Yes, with the fillers. Some are really boring, I must admit. But most of them show sides of the characters, especially the side ones, you wouldn't see otherwise. Not to mention the comic relief. There's no reason to rush into it so just enjoy it at your pace and I'm sure you'll be touched by this beautiful story. Now, it's definitely a shame that so much happened for this to culminate in Boruto but ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Wow, what an anime. So happy I watched this as one of my firsts as it has inspired me to watch so much more. It also inspired me to work out and better myself as the main character, Naruto Uzumaki, is an untalented outcast in the hidden leaf. He works harder than anyone and doesn't allow any negative opinions to enter his head. By far, one of the most likeable main characters in fiction as you only want the best for him. Aswell as the mc, the side cast is as much likeable. Shikamaru, kakashi and pervy sage (jiraiya) are incredibly encapturing and Pull you in when they're on screen. The deutaragonist, sasuke uchiha, leaves the village and is definitely one of the best parts of the show. His main goal is to kill his older brother, itachi uchiha, who slaughtered his clan. Overall I gave this anime a 9, so inspiring, many amazing characters, world building and a near perfect story. This anime is long but I recommend it to everyone. Love Naruto!

I started watching anime with Naruto. The story itself is very interesting and well made, at first I wasn't that so into it since I saw there were 300+ episodes (although a bunch of them are fillers) but as I started watching I got easily caught up in it. This anime makes you feel compassion, friendship and closure to the characters in it, the animation isn't the best but the series itself is pretty «old» so I think that's normal and not a crucial negative point. Each character has its individual story/development and their importance in the series. For example, one of the best side character of this whole anime is Shikamaru. The way his story was written and incorporated in the anime is amazing, definitely one of my favorites. As someone who started watching anime with Naruto, I would recommend the series to others also interested in starting.

Watching this series, worth watching, liked its minimalistic graphics and action. It has a great story and very unpredictable. I have started playing its game too. You can download it from here https://apkbeyond.com Uniqueness: While Naruto incorporates many elements commonly found in the shonen genre, such as epic battles, character growth, and a coming-of-age story, it also introduces several unique concepts and a vast world filled with ninjas, complex political dynamics, and intricate lore. Naruto's journey from an underdog to a powerful ninja, as well as the exploration of themes like friendship, destiny, and the pursuit of peace, contribute to its distinctiveness. Predictability and enjoyment: While certain aspects of Naruto's plot may be predictable at times, especially in terms of character development and certain story arcs, it remains a highly enjoyable series for many fans. The emotional depth, well-choreographed fights, and compelling character interactions often outweigh any predictability, especially for viewers who are fans of the shonen genre and appreciate the familiar tropes and setups it offers. Art style: Naruto's art style is fitting for the story it tells. The character designs are distinctive, and the action sequences are fluidly animated, showcasing the intensity of the battles. The use of vibrant colors and visually appealing landscapes adds to the overall aesthetic and complements the energetic nature of the series. Well-rounded characters: Naruto features a wide range of characters, each with their own unique strengths, weaknesses, and flaws. The main character, Naruto Uzumaki, is initially portrayed as an impulsive and brash individual, but as the story progresses, he matures and develops into a more thoughtful and empathetic leader. Similarly, other characters undergo significant growth, facing personal challenges and overcoming their flaws, making them relatable and multi-dimensional. Realistic reactions: While Naruto is set in a fictional world, the characters generally react to situations and events in a realistic manner, considering the circumstances they find themselves in. Their emotions, motivations, and actions are often driven by personal experiences, aspirations, and the complex relationships they have with one another. However, it's worth noting that certain exaggerated elements, such as over-the-top battles and supernatural abilities, may deviate from strict realism, which is common in the shonen genre. Enjoyment by others: Naruto has amassed a large and dedicated fanbase worldwide, and many people have found great enjoyment in the series. However, like any form of media, personal preferences can vary, and some individuals may not resonate with Naruto's storytelling or genre conventions. Factors such as personal taste, familiarity with shonen anime, and interest in themes explored in the series, such as friendship and personal growth, can influence whether someone will enjoy or dislike it. Overall, Naruto's blend of compelling characters, emotional storytelling, epic battles, and its exploration of universal themes has garnered widespread acclaim and popularity. While it may not be universally loved by everyone, its appeal to a broad audience suggests that many viewers will find it enjoyable.

What can one even write in a review for a show where youve watched 700 episodes. No words are enough really. Ofcourse theres also the point its split into two parts. Im just gonna do a small review for each. Naruto : Starts off a little slow. You have to endure the usual goofy Shounen humour. Sillyness. Pacing. Picks up the the Chuunin exam which is maybe the best tournament/exam arc of all time for me. That was the first time i started to feel it with Naruto and im gonna enjoy this long journey. Music is great. Tons of great openings. Some great fights. Rock Lee vs Gaara remains my all time favorite. The show continues to be great with the usual slowdons with some shorter fillers and boring recaps/slow pacing. Only to end with a HUGE filler end which bored me to death and i had to endure to get through and questioning if Naruto is gonna be wirth it. Ruined it a bit why i lowered it to 8/10. Shippuden : This is the big one. Where things finally start to happen. Coming from a long boring filler end i feel Shippuden went straight to the good stuff with Akatsuki and his nine tails origin. Soundtrack gets even better and so does the openings/Endings. Closer and Silhouette two of the best openings there are. The plot, with all its parts about Narutos backstory, the Ninja worlds origin, and all the important characters is incredible. The only letdown is the usual stuff. Some boring Shounen ”humor” Mostly weak female cast. And again way to much fillers. This time its more spread out. But this also means more interruptions. Not the ling boring endurance bit more annoying pace issues/interruptions because of it. Shippuden was the stronger part though since the original OST was greatly expanded and better, openings/endings likewise, plus tge greatly expanded plot and lore about the world and how it all connects and comes together to form an epic ninja tale. Why this part get tge higher 9/10. Overall: An experience and journey that is a must for people interested in the medium. A remarkable achievement despite its small flaws.

Naruto was my first anime, and it’s more than just a show—it’s an emotion. It taught me about pain, friendship, and what it means to keep going even when the world’s against you. The story has classic themes, but it never feels boring because of how deep and personal it gets. The art style fits perfectly with the emotional moments and intense battles. The characters feel real, flawed, stubborn, and full of growth. Naruto inspired me in so many ways, and watching him grow felt like growing with him. And honestly, the villains? Some of the coolest and most badass ever. Pain, Itachi, Madara—they’re not just evil, they’re deep, complex, and unforgettable. Even if you see some things coming, it doesn’t matter—you feel everything. Naruto will always have a place in my heart.

anyone would know this anime. This anime already has many fans in the world. the Naruto Shippuden series is a continuation of Little Naruto. Disclaimer: My review is purely based on the cannon episodes of Shippuden. I did not watch the filler. Naruto Shippuden is a very emotional character-driven story, and that's why I love it. Sure, it has an out-of-this-world story, with some pretty insane powers (though I do think that this is part of the anime's charm), but it's mainly the characters that carry the show. They are some of the most memorable, well-designed, iconic, and interesting characters in anime history if you ask me. Shippuden is also great from a technical standpoint. My mind is blown at how consistently fantastic, beautiful, and effective the music is. The soundtrack has its own personality, and never fails in setting the mood for any given scene. The OPs and most of the EDs are also pretty unforgettable. While Shippuden certainly has many instances of subpar animation and art, there are also many instances of absolutely phenomenal art and fight choreography that are well worth the wait. My only real issue is with one of the last arcs of the anime. I won't get into spoilers, but I thought it was, hands-down, the worst written cannon arc in all of Shippuden. This fact made the victory of that arc feel less deserved and a little hollow. That being said, the anime does end on a beautiful high note. As a whole, this anime is profoundly memorable. Because of that, I can forgive the aforementioned poorly written arc. This was a wonderful anime, and deciding to watch it from the beginning was one of the best decisions I've ever made.

If the whole anime was like Pain's arc, it would score 9, but the first arcs are pretty boring to watch and Ninja War is easily one of the worst anime arcs around, and the anime simply abandoned all the good characters from the Classic to focus on the beast drama between Naruto and Sasuke, besides having introduced several interesting characters throughout the plot but that didn't do any good in the end, and even characters that were initially well written like Obito, were spoiled in the end with the classic Discourse no Jutsu. One thing that also bothers me is the fact that they haven't explored almost anything in Naruto's universe apart from Konoha, and even in Konoha some things were left out like that political arc right after Itachi's death.

Extremely stretched without any valid reasons. This is my first time writing a review but i will try my best. Well so first what i wanna say that since everyone tastes are different so some people might not agree with me. But its okay. Naruto is a good anime. Many people hates it and many people loves some people think that this anime is average. But i actually like it. I talk about two things here that's the negatives and the positives and at the end of the review a final verdict for it. First a quick summary. I will try my best not to give any spoilers. [size=90]summary[/size] :- The main character is Naruto Uzumaki. And the story is simple he wants to be the leader of his village means hokage because he wants the villagers to recognise him. Everyone in his village thinks he is a monster and see him as nothing but a brat. Story:- Well Naruto is an overall good anime. For me its one of my top anime i ever watched. It was my first anime too. I already wrote the quick summary of it so you now have a bit of knowledge for it. The best thing i found about Naruto was the enjoyment. The enjoyment it gave me no other anime entertained me that much. It has its own positives and negatives i can't deny that. I found the story of it quite simple but it was enjoyable. I wouldn't say that it has the best storytelling but its still good many other anime does this better. Some people complain about the flashbacks well True but i think flashbacks are necessary here. The story is connected with their flashbacks there are character who has their own tragic backstory and if you want to understand them you have to watch the flashbacks it goes for villains too and why the villains became villain you need to know their backstory and than you will understand the story that's how the story was created theres a villain (antagonist) behind a villain. And that villain is the one who made the other villain a villain well it cofuse right but that's what it is you will know that when you watch the anime. I found almost every flashbacks good my favourite are [spoiler]Itachi's and sasuke's [/spoiler] story. Other flashbacks were also good but i felt a bit bored in [spoiler] obito's[/spoiler] backstory but it was still good because he was one of the villains. You might say what connection does the main story have with flashbacks like i said before if you want to understand the maim Story you need to watch the backstory. Every backstory connects with the main story the same goes for the main character he has a backstory too. Character:- Well characters are not great but still they are good there is a lot of characters but all of them doesn't get enough screen time and one of the main secondary characters is pretty useless and was almost the whole series but became a bit useful at the end of the story the same goes for others all of them has decent character development. But i didn't focus on the secondary characters that much because i didn't think that was necessary if i know the main story and female characters many people says the female character were annoying maybe some of them but i didn't find them annoying or entertaining they just weren't boring. But when it comes to the main characters they were great and entertaining Sounds:- Sounds were decent except for some OST's and OP, ED some of them are my all time favourites. Animation:- The animation was good. I won't say that it was great and top tier. Because Naruto never fucused on animation it was action anime so the fight were absolutely one of the best in all of anime. Positive:- The positives are its fighting. And the overall enjoyment. Its doesn't have the best animation or the best sounds well hear me out first its sounds aren't the best but they great. But it did good at what it should its fighting the fightings are easily top tier nobody can deny. The characters are overall good and i think you will enjoy almost every main secondary characters except one because she was useless almost the entire story. But others are great and their personality too. Negatives:- Well it has a decent amount of negatives too. Its fillers and its flashbacks also the amount of time the other characters get. It has good amount of fillers but if you don't wanna watch it than just skip them if you are like me who only cares about the main story than you can skip it. Now the flashbacks well yeah as i said before you won't quite understand the main story if you skip the flashbacks more importantly the antagonists. Almost every antagonists have their flashbacks and the flashbacks shows why the turned villain. And the flashbacks are connected to the main story. If you skip the flashbacks than at the end of the story you might think why did this villain did this and you might won't understand some of parts of the main story. It has some plot holes too but if i talk about it than i have to give spoilers so that's entirely a different thing. And for the characters just don't care about them. Final Verdict:- After reading all of this you might say that why did i rated it as 10/10. Well true. But that's because enjoyment. I never watched any anime that gave me as much enjoyment as Naruto. I watched Hunter x Hunter and Fullmetal alchemist brotherhood. Hunter x Hunter has better power system than Naruto and a better storytelling too. Fullmetal alchemist brotherhood has a better storytelling than naruto. But all of them are nothing compared to Naruto when i think of enjoyments. Maybe im being biased here. Since Naruto was the first anime ever watched so its nostalgic. But im a person who cares about personal enjoyment over anything else. Because of the enjoyment i never noticed all of the other negatives and mistakes. Some people also compare about the fact that sometimes Naruto talks with antagonists, tell them that what they are doing is bad the shouldn't do it and nicknamed this as talk no jutsu. I didn't care about this actually because i don't care about such if it was entertaining 😅. If you are someone like me who only cares about the main story then skip the fillers. Some people might not have same opinions and tastes as mine but that's okay. That was all i had to say. Hope you enjoyed stay frosty. For alternative recommendation:- Watch bleach, Hunter x Hunter. So that was all i had to say guys. It might be a bit big. But i had to make it big to tell you the reason's why i like this show. It was my first review so i hope you enjoyed this. If you read the full thing than thank you very much. (Sry for my bad English.😋)

Ignoring the filler and focusing on the main story, it is a pretty decent anime. The writing on the villains was compelling but pretty much every moral struggle that any of them had was exactly the same, the talk no jutsu meme. The characters are generally interesting and likable but non of them have any character development. Most characters are exactly the same when the show ends as when the show starts, just with slightly more context. It quite literally takes to the last canon episode for Sasuke to stop being a douche, which is saying a lot. The fight choreography was really good for important fights but lackluster for anything in between, so good on average. The show for me was a good gateway into anime but after rewatching it recently, I found that it isn't as good as I remembered and is definitely overhyped. I compare it to Star Wars where most of the content is mediocre but it creates a universe and deep lore that is very interesting and worth keeping up with.

This review contains my biased opinion Naruto for me is a classic This is the anime that got me into all the anime's I watch now Story is good, The fights are pretty cool, character design is alright Maybe some of the Arc's are drawn out, but I don't mind I do wish the quality be slightly higher but maybe that's asking too much I feel like the amount of episodes can be trimmed down slightly from removing the filler Story 8 Art 9 Sound 9 or 10 Character 8 maybe 10 Fights and regular enjoyment 10 Overall a 9 Definitely recommend watching Naruto Shippuden if you haven't.

Naruto: Shippuden was a good sequel. It provided something for Naruto fans to look forward to every week for about ten years. By the end, the viewers seemingly parted with their favourites for one last time... and then Boruto was announced almost in the same week. This, once again, was a source of nostalgia for those who grew up with it, and once again, was a complex show with tons of let-downs for many who did not start off their consumption of narrative media with Naruto. The first arc is probably better than the entirety of the prequel series (that's just a joke, it was just better than the mediocrity that so predominantly plagued Naruto). The Akatsuki was finally assembled, the fabled foes were finally pitted against our protagonists. Deidara was one of the most fun characters while he was on screen, as he always had some way to escape the dire situation he was in. Naruto had matured for good, and was much more likeable as a protagonist. The arc was great in almost its entirety, and most of the flaws were not majorly visible. Sai was a great character, and served his purpose as a replacement for Sasuke in the second arc. Naruto's efforts and training were apparently coming to fruition, as they were finally about to meet Sasuke... only for him to overpower Naruto's entire team and leave with the stated intention of never coming back. Hidan and Kakuzu were interesting villains, with both having valid reasons for joining the Akatsuki. Their fights were well-choreographed, and their powers were well explained and well thought out. The whole arc detailing Jiraiya's past with the Third Shinobi War, the search for Itachi on both sides, and the build up toward the introduction of Amegakure, Pain and Konan was astonishing to watch. Each scene of importance felt like a historical retelling, a story from the long gone past. There were many ups, there were rare downs, there were complex characters, and there were heartbreaking events. This, along with Pain's assault on the Hidden Leaf Village, Killer Bee's introduction, and the declaration of war at the Assembly of the Kage, were arguably the best parts of the story. These arcs were where the story and its author, Masashi Kishimoto, were truly allowed to shine, to use characters they had built up, introduce new and interesting characters, and progress the plot properly. Almost every part of the story up until then was great to watch. Then the Fourth Shinobi War started. At the beginning, it was built up as the greatest arc in the series yet. Every action in the preceding 400-something episodes (from both the prequel and Shippuden) had come to some sort of satisfying conclusion in the form of this massive conflict. The war was great to watch from all sides, as it felt like a story that would be told for centuries to come. Everything seemed to be going right : the previous Kage made an appearance, Madara was a great villain, and the true nature of the events up until now was revealed. All seemed to be going well : fillers, while predominant, did not take much from the show in terms of quality, and the story was great, to say the least. And then the show kept on going, stretching the War arc with one twist after another. The first few were anticipated, but as the arc went on, it got much more random. Another flaw the show had was that, even as time evolved, it made barely any effort to evolve its animation and colour pallette till the last arc. Much of it was bland rather than dark, and many scenes were slow in terms of both movement and dialogue. And right in the middle, for no reason, was just a random 7-episode Itachi backstory, adapted from a series of light novels not even written by the original author. Where the show truly lost me, and many other viewers, was the introduction of Kaguya. Her story was sad, but her motivations made no sense, and she seemed to exist purely to conclude the series as a whole. Madara was put out of commission without any warning, and for no reason, and most of the power-ups were done for plot convenience, since the protagonists had had enough of losing. The show managed to somewhat save its plummeting story with the final showdown between Naruto and Sasuke, but the damage had already been done over the course of about 100 episodes. Critiquing the music and art would be meaningless - both were great, just like the previous installment in the series. When the show shined, when it had potential, the viewer could only hope for it to evolve into something generational. While it did in terms of the influence it had, it severely lacked that quality in its narrative. Impactful parts hit as hard as the bad parts disappointed. The sheer length of the show acted as its saviour; everything up until the war's downs (and there was a lot) was great. Naruto: Shippuden was definitely much better than its prequel, had everything going for it for the first 70% of the show, yet when it came to concluding the series, it did anything it could to just reach that point, even if it made no sense.

Again, I skipped the filler in this show. Say what you want about the rating and the payoffs and the pitfalls but let me tell you guys this show made me cry (you all know what specific character death I'm talking about here) laugh, rage and everything in-between. You come to care for character's you never thought you would more than you ever thought you would. You're invested in their lives and in the plot and despite all it's flaws I can't help but say the hate is not deserved. Shippuden is really great, even better than the original imo, and you can come to your own conclusion upon finishing it (believe me I have qualms myself) but please do give it a try.

Story: 9 I really love the story, and -spoiler- the storyline gets exponentially more complicated and I really like that. The mediocre 'me = best ninja and my friend ran away, I must get him back' changed to some masterminds with mindf*ck plans that actually make sense! If you're a kid, you won't get what happened after the first arc with Sai. Art: 1 It's not exactly the art, it's the animation. It's like they don't care if the animation is any good. They slagged off with the starting of shippuden and I really can't give a higher grade than an 1 Sound: 5 It had some great OP and ED's, especially bacchoi!! I really like most of the voices. Some of them are anoying, like sakura, but in general it's quite good. Character: 6 I dislike a lot of them. A lot of them are just annoying, like sakura, but there are some characters who are just epic wins! I would like to praise Itachi, Deidara, Jiraiya, Pain, Shikamaru, Hinata and Kiba. Overall: 7 I would give it 8 if the animation was ANY good
