This anime is incredible, one of the best ninja stories of the entire century. Something so motivating, inspiring and beautiful that is considered a classic in the world of animation. The music, visuals and characters connect with the entirety of the human soul. Yes there are flaws, yes there are filler and so on. However that does not truly determine how amazing this story is, the history, world building, storyline and the aesthetic in general is what makes it stand out. The story is set in this blend of Japanese feudalistic society mixed in with current technological innovations, the atmosphere is set in this brutal world of war and conquest. In which there is this constant tension of war between empire like nations, in this show we get the perspective of The Hidden Leaf (Konoha). A village superpower with a diverse range of clans with different abilities. In this society we meet our protagonist Naruto Uzumaki, a mischievous boy who lives as an orphan. Compared to the original show in Shippuden, you can see him grow as a teenager and see how he matures and understands the harsh realities of human nature and the world. Simple messages are portrayed in a complex fashion especially in the upcoming arcs, were villains are too allowed their perspective and how they came to be. At times as human beings there are plenty of life lessons and reminders that Naruto Shippuden excellently shows such as the importance of loved ones and friends, a basic concept that allows human beings to bring meaning and to flourish. Secondly the importance of hatred and how traumatic events can haunt one forever, as we see in Saskue Uchiha From the characters each one has a difficult past or reality that they must deal with forever. Discrimination towards Naruto for having the nine tails inside him and the Uchiha clan, PTSD from war and a loss of comrades, and so on. Real life aspects that are expressed onto this story. On a personal level, this show has brought much inspiration, strength and reconciliation that has truly changed my teenage years as a whole. Overall this show is recommended to everyone, especially for those who are into history, philosophy, literature, mythology , cool fights scenes or simply someone who yearns for the light in times of darkness. Thank you Kishimoto and all the animators who participated in this masterpiece of art.

I watched naruto shippuden when I was 13 years old, so while I remember a lot of it I don't really remember enough to write a detailed review. It was ok. I skipped all the filler btw. **SPOILERS AHEAD.** Not major ones, but spoilers nonetheless. Pain arc was definitely the highlight. Sakura was useless for nearly all 500 episodes. Itachi's story was really well written. The akatsuki were a well written group, and I really liked Madara. Not a fan of the Otsutsuki. A real asspull because the author couldn't figure out how Naruto and Sasuke could defeat Madara. So overall I'd say it's ok. If the filler was cut I'd say it's good.

I keep my reviews short, simple, and to the point for those of you who don’t want to read the rest of these essays. If you liked Naruto, you will like naruto shippuden, it is absolutely worth your time. Do not watch shippuden unless you have already seen the 2002 naruto. This is a continuation of naruto. The fights are hype, the new villains are awesome, and there’s a huge improvement in characters. The world is expanded on even further, the story picks up and is fast paced. The powers get even cooler. We are blessed with some awesome music/openings. It gets surprisingly emotional at times, which you would not expect of this show. There are some must see fight scenes with legendary animation and build up. It has a problem with too many repetitive flashbacks, but you can skip through them so it isn’t unbearable. It sets up nicely for Boruto, which is the next continuation, while leaving you with a satisfying and conclusive end even if you are never to watch boruto. There are filler episodes like in the 2002 naruto and as I said in that review you can skip them and not miss out on the story, however if you have the time I would still go ahead and check them out if you are a fan. You can also just go back and watch them after you finish the main show. They are enjoyable and I do not regret sitting through them. If you are still hungry for more naruto after you finish, check out the movies.

"Naruto Shippuuden" gets me nostalgic AF. It's the one anime that you can't stop thinking about for weeks after completion.The story and the plot is pretty awesome. Action scenes were also nice. Sometimes the animation sucked, but the story took care of it. For example, the pain arc .It has some plot holes, like deidora could use self explosion repeatedly in edo form. But the only thing that keeps me away from rating it a 10 is its "FILLERS". The first impression of 500 episodes scares the shit out of people .Still, overall it is a pretty decent one .I would highly recommend anyone who has patience and guts to watch it. And skip the fillers if you want. You won't miss anything by doing so.

Naruto Shippuden is a legendary anime. It is old and it it brings back memories from the childhood. From the beginning i want to say that i only put 9 on overall because the enjoyment pull down the grade (i did put 6 because of fillers. 41% of the anime is with fillers). [this review may contain spoilers!!!] 1. STORY: The story is amazing. It is about a ninja that want to become the best one and he also wants to become the hokage (LEADER) of the Hidden Leaf Village (Konoha). The story got many good things but the story is also sad sometimes (some character die). From the beginning of series Narut, the main character is looking for his friend that left the village and join the Orochimaru team (Orochimaru is a villain). The story is most based on finding Sasuke (his lost friend). So i thing in the end the story is ok. Beginning and the End are so good 2. ART: The art it's very good because the Naruto shippuden was started in 2007 and in comparison with other anime the art and graphics are cool. 3. SOUND: The sound is amazing. It is so different from the others. It brings me old memories. 4. Characters: The characters from this masterpiece are incredible. One of them i think are made in joke because are so useless in the anime but Naruto, Sasuke, Itachi, Obito, Kakashi, Madara, The 4th Hokake, etc. are so powerfull, good costumizated and got lot of good personality. 5. Enjoyment: The anime is very good but the fillers are so annoying because they are in the middle of a good fight or somthing light that. I am saying it again: there are 41% of the anime fillers..... -----Overall----- The anime is great but the fillers are annoying. So the anime is 9/10 but i will give 10/10 because it brings me good memories of chilhood.

Ok first I loved this show. Well it entertained me so much.it entairned me for 7years .It taught some best life leasson that you can't learn from school .Well the fillers are high but some of them are good and some of them are serious waste of time. Well when I started to watch it the land of mist arc was not that much good but after that the chunin exam were the greatest arc in the og we got to see lot abt characters like neji, lee, ino-shika-cho trio, hinata, shino kina etc after the gaara's introduction and legendary sannins were great. And in shippiden we have got more characters. Villians: I think u can get more great villians in naruto than most animes like first we got orochimaru then itachi kisame and the whole Akatsuki. The pain was a badass and his arc changed everything. But the real master of manipulation were tobi and madara. Madara was built different. Story writing: The story was good but at the war arc it was whole twisted and our beloved villian doesn't get a good ending bad story writing of the whole arc. Character: characters were good except girls like sakura, ino, ten ten. But the male characters were good written. Tips: Naruto is a God anime my tip is that you don't have watch all fillers because it is not connected to story. And some fillers at last of the series were important ( ie, hagoromo's past) beside this everything is good. So watch and enjoy😊

A very reasonable title, cut with filler and flashbacks to the point of being barely watchable much of the time. When in doubt, jump to a flashback. If in doubt about a flashback, put a flashback in your flashback. Are we at the climax of the series? Better bump it up to 90% flashback content. Can't remember what's going on because of all the flashbacks? Better recap — with a flashback. The producers of the Naruto Shippuden anime milked what I assume was a pretty good manga for easily three to four times its value by turning exceptionally bad hack writers loose on the story between installments of the manga, and by... well, it's like that time... When in doubt, jump to a flashback. If in doubt about a flashback, put a flashback in your flashback. Are we at the climax of the series? Better bump it up to 90% flashback content. And then there was that other time... ...Cut with filler and flashbacks to the point of being barely watchable much of the time. ...Better recap — with a flashback. ...Are we at the climax of the series? Well, I'm sure you get the gist of why this should have been a much, MUCH shorter series. That, and the Yota mini-arc. Seriously, **** that guy.

Oh, indeed it's the ever so popular Naruto Shippuden. Ready to waste mindless hours watching yet another dragged on Shounen Anime? I sure am! Story: It's Naruto! Of course the story is going to be pretty sappy looking. Ya'know with the Sasuke and bonds stuff. But the thing is it is executed well. So the anime in the nutshell is. Naruto has left Konoha for a period of 3 years with The Legendary Sennin Jiraiya. Within these 3 years he has been training for future endeavors. Aswell within these 3 years everyone seems to hit puberty and have a major growth spurt. The former chunnin ninja have become adept, some of which have become jounin. After Naruto's fated return. His team is reunited with the classic bell retrieval test. Sakura and Naruto work together to steal the bells. They both demonstrate magnificent skill. Resulting in the reconsaince of Team Kakashi. However Kakashi is always missing or injured so Team Kakashi is lacking as a team. A mysterious new ninja and a Anbu member join the team. This is when the ultimate goal of Team Kakashi uncovers. To retrieve Sasuke and destroy Akatsuki. Seems Legit 8/10. Art: The art has improved over the original resulting a much more enjoyable experience. However overuse of certain animations is a huge turn off. Seeing the same traveling animation is quite irritating. Character Models however are very well thought out and designed. 6/10 Sound: I'm a sucker for good OPs, and NS has a good amount. Specifically Sha La La. Aswell the voice actors did a magnificent job. They aged everyones voice quite well. This would be a perfect 10 if it did not lack in actual Sound Effects which would be reused to death. 8/10. Characters: 8/10. They were good. Not quite sure how to say how without spoilers but whatever. Enjoyment: It is so far a very exciting watch. A very good replacement for Bleach. 9/10

I should mention that I binge-watched this show and skipped about 95% of the fillers. I will try to keep this review spoiler free. Naruto Shippuden takes place about 2.5 years after the events which transpired in the original Naruto series. Sasuke Uchiha deserted the Hidden Leaf Village and joined up with the sinister Orochimaru to gain more power in his quest to kill his brother and avenge his family. Naruto Uzumaki decided to train with Jiraiya in order to improve his skill so he could get Sasuke back to his side. Meanwhile the threat of the organization called Akatsuki drives ever closer, who are out to capture Naruto. The story is rarely the strong point of a shonen anime. It often comes down to a villain who is drunk on power and who wants to take control of the world. In that regard Naruto Shippuden is not that much different. At the start it’s simple, but effective. Without spoiling too much I found that the story did get a bit too convoluted at the end, but I imagine it can be difficult to try and wrap it all up. I will say however that almost each villain has his own unique reason for why they want to achieve world domination. In some cases, I found myself even sympathizing with the villains. The line between good and bad is blurry and often there are flashbacks which explain why a villain has had a change of heart and why he or she has those different ideologies. There are a lot of interesting and tragic themes such as pain, isolation and destiny. These different motivations bring more depth to the villains. This is why I found the characters to be the best part of the show. There is the typical shonen protagonist Naruto Uzumaki. He is a total goofball, yet very dependable at the same time. He works and trains the hardest and he has the ability to connect with other people. He’s a good main character and I found myself cheering for him throughout the whole show. Sasuke Uchiha at the other hand is the complete opposite of Naruto. He is “cool”, very talented, all the girls swoon over him, but he struggles with himself and mainly with his past. Even throughout the original Naruto show I found Sasuke to be a very polarizing character. At points I disliked him and at other points I sort of liked him. This trend continued for me in Naruto Shippuden. Then there are a lot of other characters, who all have their own powers and weaknesses. We of course have all the Hidden Leaf Ninjas. We get introduced to ninjas from other villages. Some characters from the past get more fleshed out. Finally, we have the villains. I already made mention of the them up above. Pain and Itachi are some of my favorite characters in any anime ever. So, all in all that leaves us with more than 50 important characters. All of them are unique and you’ll find yourself picking favorites for some of these characters. Some of them focus on long distance, while others are hand to hand combat specialists. If you watched the original Naruto you will know there is a big difference between a Shikamaru or a Rock Lee fight. The main problem with having so many characters however is that not every character gets developed or his/her time to shine. In the original Naruto show we saw minor characters having proper 1 on 1 fights during the Chunin Exams and during the Sasuke Recovery arcs. They got multiple episodes and often you saw flashbacks of their pasts. This way you got interested in some of those characters and you had your favorites. Because so many new characters get introduced during Shippuden – and since we do not have THAT many villains – some of these ninjas do not get any fights during the whole of Shippuden. This is a shame since I was invested in some of them and subsequently didn’t get to see if they learned new techniques or improved. Their characters in effect didn’t develop much / at all. In addition, there is also a bit too much powering up going on to my liking. The fighting, the techniques and the damage inflicted all get turned up a few scales. Some characters even get buffed/evolve multiple times during one fight, which makes them literally (demi) gods. Other characters meanwhile stay behind. I believe this is called power creep? Another strong point of this show is the setting, the world of Naruto. How someone can come up with ideas and concepts like ninja villages, ninjutsu, genjutsu, kages, tailed beasts and how all that stuff is connected, is beyond me. It’s genius and it’s all carefully laid out and explained in this show. Just like in the original Naruto show, the soundtrack is amazing. There are some tracks which will pump you up for another great fight, and there are tracks which will hit you right in the feels. There are 20 different openings and 40 different endings. I’m sure you will find something you like and dislike. Personally, I liked the opening track called Silhouette by KANA-BOON the most. The animation is good. It can be a bit inconsistent and there is an obvious change of pace when high action episodes occur. I like the style of animation which gets used during those high actions episodes. It is more fluid, but I could understand if people didn’t like it. The fights and more specifically the hand to hand combat scenes are often amazing; even mesmerizing. I don’t like it though when the animation in openings already spoil upcoming events or matchups. This happened a couple of times. I feel like I also should mention something about the fillers. I binge-watched Naruto Shippuden and I skipped 95% of the fillers. I recommend you to do the same. I watched about 80 fillers of the original Naruto and they were mostly dreadful. 40% of the episodes are fillers so look on some website or in the forums here to find out which episodes are skippable. I recommend watching the Kakashi and Itachi focused fillers. They were enjoyable. The downside of binge-watching is that some of the repeated flashbacks are skippable as well. There are so many flashbacks in Naruto. It’s insane how often they for example showed Sasuke’s past with Itachi. I get that it’s really important, but they’ll show you the exact same scene about 5 times. If you watch 1 episode per week these flashbacks might be welcome (although I can imagine these kinds of viewers would rather want new and original content), but if you watch all the episodes in rapid succession then I’d say the repeated flashbacks are filler-esque too, unless you have a terrible memory. Overall, I would say that I really enjoyed this anime. I binge-watched this at a high pace during a somewhat difficult time in my life. I was always curious to find out what was going to happen next. At some point I was thinking about giving this a 10/10, but I decided with a 9.5/10 because of some nitpicking during the final arc. A day after I watched the final episode I just had a bit of an empty feeling as a huge, fun part of my evening and night disappeared. I am sad it ended, but I really enjoyed the ride. Let’s hope Boruto will prove to be a worthy sequel.

Naruto Shippuden is a masterful continuation of Naruto's story, and as a series it even manages to improve upon its' predecessor - an anime which already needed little improving, in my opinion. Still, it has its' own drawbacks which will be off putting for some viewers, which I'll go over. The story provides more of the action adventure found in Naruto, while the plot really matures appropriate to the characters' ageing up. The mysterious Akatsuki organisation establish a threat right from the start, while maintaining suspense through many episodes as each character is revealed slowly, one at a time. These villains provide situations that feel truly perilous for our heroes, and the show packs in a solid handful of emotional gut-punches throughout. The arcs are varied enough to hold the viewer's interest across a long series, and bring focus to characters other than Naruto; as well as battling Akatsuki members, there are arcs focused on Naruto's training, on Sasuke's activities, or on revealing important mysteries and backstories. Now, there are still weak points to the story. There are some overpowered techniques conveniently used, such as Izanagi, Rinne Rebirth, or the 100 Healings. Several times characters are saved from certain death by such powers. While this might be an annoyance for viewers at times, ultimately I think Naruto has enough tragedy in its premise and across Shippuden's story, without becoming bleak by piling up too many corpses of beloved characters. Towards the end the story does teeter on the edge of the trap of 'too many villain reveals': "I'm the villain- no I'M the real villain- no, fools, it was me all along!". This isn't Shippuden's strongest hour, but it does serve to add a cool sense of destiny and fated conflict for our heroes, so if you enjoy that kind of element in stories, you won't be displeased. And - ultimately - the real final conflict is the one you knew was coming since the very beginning of Naruto, and when it comes at long last, it won't disappoint. To me, it delivers an emotionally charged and satisfying payoff to a series which I have followed for many years, and it's an arc I am happy to rewatch regularly. Overall, there are no unanswered questions left at the end, no frustrating ambiguity, and I think it is well worth spending 500 episodes to reach such a satisfying conclusion. The characters have always been Naruto's strongest asset, and that's no different in Shippuden. Our protagonists have spent time becoming stronger, they're more emotionally mature and (sometimes) wiser. My favourite example of this development across the time skip is Sakura, who really comes into her own in Shippuden. There is still plenty of room for growth for them across the series, and we get to see many of the large cast shine on their own. The histories of some fan favourite characters are slowly revealed, to great effect, any many new characters are added to the cast. By far and away the greatest of these new additions is that most beloved villain organisation in anime: the Akatsuki! And they're beloved for good reason. They are equal parts intimidating and badass; at times even goofy. They range from sympathetic anti-heroes, to assholes who are having so much fun being assholes that you can't help but love them a little bit. Each member is given adequate screen time to showcase their unique abilities and personalities, but even so, they're so enjoyable to spend time with that it's almost bittersweet to see them defeated; I just can't get enough of watching them. Of course, within any show, not every character can be perfect, and for me in Shippuden, Karin really takes the crown as the worst character in the entire Naruto-verse. Constantly annoying and adds nothing to the plot. Fortunately she is only a minor character, so we're not overrun with screen time for her. Conversely, the character of Killer B, who I admit I find tiresome at times in the manga, I actually find less annoying and more tolerable in the anime. The last thing I'll mention in terms of character is the slight pitfall which I think Shippuden falls into during it's latter half; that is a still expanding cast of less important characters. While they retain unique and memorable character design, the addition of a new set of characters from the nations neighbouring the Land of Fire ultimately doesn't add all that much to the story. I think this is because there isn't enough time to develop them much at the late stage of the anime, and they end up relying largely on gimmicks rather than fleshed out personalities (examples are the Fifth Mizukage and Omoi). This just means that if these characters are in peril, it's hard to care too much about it. The music in this series is absolutely outstanding. There is a new composer, Yasuhara Takanashi, who continues many elements and themes as to feel like a seamless transition between series, while introducing many beautiful pieces of his own, and appropriately badass character themes for many new villains. Some of the most standout tracks of the OST are Senya (or Many Nights), Girei, and Hyouhaku (or Wandering). It's an OST that I have continued to listen to frequently for more than 10 years. Of the many opening songs, a couple are average; the rest range from good to brilliant. The best ones do their job of pumping you up for the action, and provide an emotional kick for viewers invested in the characters. The best examples of this are Blue Bird, Sign, Diver, and Silhouette. Special mention also goes to Hero's Come Back!!, which was perfectly chosen as the first opening of Shippuden. It you come to this anime after Naruto and aren't pumped already, then this opening does that job for you - the song coupled with animation that includes a really badass shot of the mysterious Akatsuki organisation is enough to get anyone excited. To note; I watch the English dub, and I enjoy it immensely. I have still watched plenty of episodes in Japanese, as for most of the time I watched it the English dubbed episodes were a little behind the Japanese release; I don't think there's any notable shift in tone or quality between the two, so whichever one you prefer I think will be equally enjoyable. A notable mention goes to Vic Mignogna and Michael Yurchack who both voice versions of a character who is introduced later in the series, and stood out to me as unique and memorable voices for an important character. There's little to say about the art other than: it's just good. It's pleasant to look at, and the fight scenes are visually exciting. The lines look cleaner than it's predecessor. The palette retains a lot of it's vibrancy, though it becomes desaturated through certain arcs appropriate to the tone of the story, as our heroes face more serious threats and losses. The main drawback of Shippuden is much the same as Naruto's: an excessive amount of filler. And unlike it's predecessor the filler arcs are interspersed throughout the main story, so if you are intent on avoiding them, it takes a little more effort to do so (i.e. looking up filler lists online). However, I would say that some of the filler is quite enjoyable; the different tailed-beast arcs, Kakashi's Anbu arc, and Itachi's Shinden arc spring to mind. Also, a lot of the filler in later episodes tries to delve into some of the supporting characters, rather than being just meaningless monster-of-the-week fodder. Additionally, some later filler arcs are actually based on light novels that accompany the manga, rather than being anime-only. Ultimately, I think the filler isn't as big an issue for new viewers as it was for fans watching along as episodes were released (it could certainly make you impatient when waiting for the story to advance, back in the day); but any new viewer can use their discretion to decide whether to watch or skip ahead. Overall, Naruto and Shippuden have retained their position as my favourite anime of all time since I first started watching, more than a decade ago. I love being immersed in the world and I find the central themes and conflicts to be heartening, and emotionally satisfying. There are several arcs that I enjoy rewatching regularly on their own, and at any given point I'm itching to rewatch the whole series again, filler and all. For fans of Naruto I think it's highly worth seeing how the story develops and concludes in Shippuden. For viewers who are reluctant to watch Naruto (maybe it seems a little young) and want to jump in at Shippuden, I think it's possible. The backstories of the characters are revisited enough that it's probably not too hard to understand or follow, though I do think you'd be missing out on some critical character bonding from the first part.

Original Naruto is probably my most beloved anime of all time. I would always go back and watch any arc and still find something that makes me watch 20-30 more episodes without feeling bored. Music is fantastic, animation is very good for the time being and plot for is very complex and yet simple to understand. I wish i could say same thing about Shippuuden. First 3-4 arcs kept the same pace and value to plot as original story. As i personally find Gaara arc not as great as later one i still can see meaning to be there. It introduced whole new enemy for protagonists and served as jump for series to more mature climate which i was hoping to stay until the end. Orochimaru/Sasuke and Shikamaru arcs only proved that this direction was right and gave us fantastic and memorable moments. I was invested in every single character introduced to the series up till this point in the series and waited for new episode to come out with excitement and hype. Until of course infamous Pain arc that started with big impact and ended with probably most awful and mediocre way that became the solution for every single problem in the anime. That is of course Naruto being the messiah that turns every enemy into his friend and make everything meaningless that happens in the past. Akatsuki mystery and threat built for almost half of the Shippuuden was just scrapped and every following arc became predictable despite having lot of turning points and amazing fights. The War had some great fights and showcases of characters but who cared at this point, because it was so stretched and had probably most fillers in history of anime ever. And of course we had 3 switches of main antagonist in like 2 years without ending a single battle. It became unwatchable and even animation started to look awful somewhere on the road. As much as i love Naruto franchise overall, i honestly can't give Shippuuden any score higher than 5. It showed potential at the beginning but it was butchered in the end. I find that just sad and i wish that show had more great storytelling and animation.

Naruto shippuden had great promise but was ultimately let down, let me explain. Lets start with what Naruto shippuden does well. Its characters: A diverse and interesting set of characters and while there is a lot it feels like the majority of them get enough screen time and backstory to justify them being there. The world: Naruto shippudens world is truly something to behold, Just the fact that its a world full of ninjas with different clans is cool enough but its a lot more than just that, As the show grows so does the world and we the viewer slowly starts to grasp just how intricate and mysterious it can be. Fights: While there are good and bad fights in every shounen for such a long show Naruto does have a consistent amount of good ones, Like other shounens such as Bleach these fights are gripping due to the fact that each ninja and ninja clan have a diverse set of tools and jutsus (techniques/ability's) giving us something new and fresh pretty much every fight. Moving on to what the show does ok at best. Animation: Super inconsistent. One episode can look great because they wanted to put a bit more budget into it and then the episode after can look nothing like the last, This can be demoralising and disappointing for a viewer who is expecting consistent animation. The show can look great but only if they want it to which most of the time is not the case as they want to save money. Sound (OP's/ED's): The openings and ending at the start of the show are a wonder to listen to they really put you in the right mood to enjoy the show no complaints here except for the fact that the openings gradually get a tiny bit worse throughout but that is bound to happen. The problem lies in the sound/music that happens during the episode itself not at the end or start. The music to me is too slow and sombre for what the anime is centered around which is ninjas and keep in mind these are not the type of ninjas who meditate they are the ones who throw goddamn meteors out of the sky (get what i am saying). I am not saying its bad its just ok, average if you will. Now lets get on to the bad: The story: The story of Naruto shippuden as a whole is fine in fact i would consider it good as it keeps the viewer watching by slowly revealing more about the world and whats really going on under the surface but its just not enough to save it from the curse that is fillers. 42% of Naruto shippuden is filler , Yes you heard me correct, No i am not memeing 42 goddamn percent , mother of god. Before you go crazy hear me out, While a large portion of Naruto shippuden is filler its not necessarily bad filler and to be honest i think some of the filler is needed as there are so many characters that get their backstory from said fillers, but even with that being said it is just way way too much and unfortunately because of this filler another problem rises from the ground like a weed. With loads of fillers comes pacing issues and these aren't some minor pacing issues because while a lot of fillers are obviously going to be slow paced the fillers actually make the pacing of the non filler episodes suffer aswell, also if you choose to skip fillers you will miss out on a lot of character development and backstory as that is the general use of them in the show, its a lose lose situation. I could rant about this for days but lets leave it there for now. Now that i have mentioned the good, the ok and the ugly lets move on to. Overall thoughts: Naruto shippuden is your classic shounen and because of this it suffers from the classic shounen problems those being terrible pacing and horrendous amounts of filler episodes which hold back what could have been an incredible show thanks to the awesome characters and world, Leaving the show only average towards the end. If you don't mind slow pacing and a huge amount of filler and give the show a fair shot you may find yourself entranced by Naruto shippuden's character and world building.

this show was average at best, half the show was filler and the other half was just meh for the most part. i felt that my enjoyment for the show peaked at the pain arc, but then after that it was just me finishing the show because i was already halfway through and i figured i might as well finish the show. 500 episodes of a meh anime, i no watch again :) but in all seriousness i did enjoy a fair bit of the show, mainly the first half and remember that this is just my opinion so if you liked it, that just means you found something good in this show that i did not and i hope you did cause otherwise thats 500 episodes down the drain

This review is for all of the Naruto series. "a 7/10 show with 12/10 moments." This quote, along with the addition of some 10/10 characters, sums up my experience with the Naruto series pretty well. I am in no way saying that Naruto Shippuuden along with it's prequel are flawless pieces of media, in fact far from it, but I cannot ignore the lasting impact this show managed to place on me. I believe it's important to take this show for what it is rather than allow ourselves to be blinded by nostalgia, so to quickly bring up some of the problems within the series I'll start with the frankly terrible writing of majority of the female characters. It is no secret that the girls in this show have some downright pitiful writing compared to the male ones, and there really isn't any way to excuse that. Throughout the majority of the show the girl characters seem to be used as plot devices to help forward the development of the primarily male cast, and seeing as Naruto is a battle shounen, this unfortunately comes as little surprise to me. Aside from this obvious fault, the other main problem that I'm sure everyone has heard much about is the sheer amount of filler. It is an undeniable fact that if your show is 700+ episodes long with over 40% of those being filler, there's a problem. This being said however, I understand why this was done, and don't see a problem if you choose to skip the filler episodes as Naruto is already a long series as is. Personally however, as long as I like the characters, I can find enjoyment in some filler arcs, that is if they are not shoved in the middle of an important story arc. There are other flaws such as the poor writing of the over 200 episode long war arc and the lack luster finale of this serious commitment of a show, but setting aside the bad lets touch on what makes this series so good. My love for the Naruto series stems from the pure attachment you get to it's characters, I mean how can you not after spending 720 episodes watching them grow and achieve their goals, as well as suffer from loss and hardships. It may sound cheesy, but after basically growing up with these characters for years of my childhood, they hold a special place in my heart, and therefore the impact of character death or growth hits that much harder. Something I really commend the Naruto series for is the writing of the "villains." They have you questioning what is truly good and evil, with most all the villains having a clear and sometimes rather convincing motive for why they do what they do, which is something I don't see too often in shows. Often times in media villains are just chocked up to the baseless cliche of "taking over the world" or just being downright comically evil, but I don't see that happening in Naruto. It is really hard to hate most of this shows antagonists, as you find yourself questioning whether these "bad guys" are really all that bad. In a classic battle of ideologies mixed with some beautifully choreographed fight scenes, the clash between the expansive cast of equally lovable characters is something you can't look away from. Aside from the villains, the rivalry explored between our main characters, Naruto and Sasuke, is what I believe to be one of the most enthralling dynamics in all of shounen. Watching the unbroken dance of emotions surrounding these two as they combat each other in passionate battles of skill and wit, as well as the internal mental conflict that they each face, is one of the most emotionally investing stories that I've had the joy of experiencing. Between the constant battle of love and hatred they feel for one another and the shattered bonds they share with their own home and family, the war going on within these two boys' minds and hearts is sincerely something to behold. It truly is a wonderful journey of growth and acceptance that while full of pain and heartbreak along the way, ultimately reaches a a conclusion that is wholeheartedly worth it. I find myself going back to watch the finale of their concluding fight more than I'd like to admit, but it's just that good. This iconic duo is one that is sure to be remembered for years to come. TLDR; Naruto has the power to make you fall head over heels for it's characters and world, you'll find yourself laughing and crying along side them, and before you know it the once daunting series may start to not feel as long. By the end I was yearning for more, wishing to see my favorite shinobi go on more adventures together, strengthening their bonds, experiencing joys and sorrows, and most of all continuing to make the Naruto series what it is; an experience worth remembering. I can safely say that while Naruto has undoubtedly gone down in history as one of the most iconic anime series out there, the lessons and emotions that came along with it will be forever etched in our hearts as well.

So, I loved Naruto Part 1, and then I watched Shippuden, really excited for more Naruto, especially after everyone hyped it up for me. What I got is one of the most boring, mediocre anime I've ever seen. At least in the shonen genre. Let's begin with the story. STORY: After the amazing arcs in part 1, I was ready for some more amazing writing. Well, the first arc in Shippuden bored me out of my mind. I literally dropped the series for a few months just because I couldn't watch it. The second arc, Tenchi Bridge was a little bit more enjoyable, but we basically got a Kakashi and Sasuke rip off, taking the worst elements of both of the characters and creating two horrible new useless characters! The third arc was ok, it felt kind of dragged on in the 3rd act but it was good overall. The 4th arc brought Shippuden back the the writing of part 1, and oh my god it was amazing. There was tons of emotion, rich character development, and amazing fights and moments, just like part 1. I didn't like the ending to the arc, but it was mediocre at worst. The 4th arc was amazing over all. The 5th arc kind of felt dragged out, and it had poor character writing with Sasuke, Naruto and Sakura that I'll get into soon. It was really just set up for the 6th arc. The 6th arc was a giant arc, that had some amazing moments that I still love, great fights, and a amazing villain, probably one of my favorite villains of all time, but even then felt dragged out, boring and had HORRIBLE character writing. And don't get me started to the ending of Shippuden. It made me hate the show for giving me one of the worst endings ever, after I had spent over 500 episodes watching it. And there was a hell of a lot of filler, which I got fed up with and just pulled out a filler list and skipped all of the filler. Over all, the story was bad at some parts, ok at some parts, and AMAZING at other parts. It did have a ton of potential. 7/10. ART: The visuals sucked ass. I hated the art so much that it gave me eye cancer. Of course, when the show wanted to, it looked amazing. A few moments that I don't wanna spoil come to mind. Compared to part 1's bright visuals, its shit when they make it too bland and dark. Overall, 6/10. SOUND: Compared to the happy and amazing music of part 1, shippudens's music(apart from the op's and ed's) was horrible. I srsly hated this music. Its just a bunch of violins just screeching. Overall: 3/10. CHARACTER: Some characters get development, but most get pushed to the side. Shikamaru gets a ton of development. but Kiba gets none. Its just shit character writing. Sasuke has some of the worst development in anime, like this guy goes from wanting to kill his bro, to wanting to do some crazy crap that I think made no sense. Sakura had development at the start of Shippuden, but then goes back to being a Sasuke simp pretty soon. Naruto also becomes a complete Sasuke simp, always chasing after him and wanting him to come back. Sasuke literally told him a billion times to just stay away from him and stop being annoying. But Naruto just can't do that, huh? Kakashi barely gets development other than us learning his back story. And don't get me started on talk no jutsu. Remember when Naruto convinced Zabuza to be a good guy at the very end? Yeah now he does that with almost every villain in the story. It sucks. But I won't lie, some characters do get character development. So overall its a 6/10. ENJOYMENT: Even though there was numerous problems, I actually had a fun time watching Shippuden. I did get really bored in the first arc, and during the war. But in the other arcs had fun. It was an enjoyable ride, but I couldn't enjoy it as much as part 1 because of how shit everything else was. Overall: 7/10. OVERALL: I thought it was decent. So a 4/10. I will still recommend it if u watched part 1 of naruto and loved it a hell of a lot. But don't except the same amazing writing, character, and all the other stuff. It doesn't help that Chakra just gets way too OP by the end of the show and it just becomes DBZ. But overall if u are gonna watch it, skip the filler, and anything u think is unecesary. See ya, and I hope this review helped.

Naruto is an amazing anime that everyone should enjoy. The story is just amazing, they have such a great focus on all the character, you will definitely like every character, and not only the main people. Also they use the "set up pull off" technic very well, there are a lot of surprises along the way aswell whitch will definitely take you off guard. I have been emotianally toutched many times in this anime, which was not something that I thought i would be when I first started watching it. The music is simply amazing, both the intro and outro songs, but also the random songs that gets played. It is absolutely amazing and really helps the atmosphere. As far as i know, this is one of the best anime that is out there and it is definitely worth watching If I should point out some of the bad things (which there are) then it has to be that there are so many episodes that it is starting to look like it will never end. Also there are so many fillers in there, and it can get kind of enoying at times. I wil highly recommend Naruto and Naruto Shippuden to anyone

I have to say, I dropped Naruto for a while and was ready to throw in the towel on the series. Then Shippuuden came along. The first few episodes in this series show growth in Naruto, something I waited desperately for, but he actually partially regresses as time moves on. Also, there was nothing really interesting happening around him. In fact, the two most interesting story arcs in Shippuuden were all about other characters. And what happens to Naruto while we're given an in-depth character development of a character that we've never seen before, that's not important to the overall plot and that we know will be defeated? Naruto jumps on logs. He jumps on logs chasing a guy whose power is to create clay birds. That's several episodes where all Naruto does is jump on logs, in a circle, trying to catch this clay guy. Yeah... All in all, Naruto Shippuuden is much like Naruto. It has some great moments, but it's just not worth looking through all the crap between them. Shippuuden seems to have fewer filler episodes and more filler content and bad writing. It's not the worst anime series out there, but to me it's just a big waste of time.

Disclaimer: I have read the manga and have spoilers are hard to avoid "ex. Boruto" so this review will include an "ending" review. Naruto Shippuden. I feel conflicted, I want to love Naruto but the amount of trash that I have to endure.. Is it worth it? I haven't really been to active in the anime community. Probably cause I don't enjoy that much anime anymore. I pick apart anime too much. I should just watch it for fun and not look deep into its construction... WRONG! Story: 5 Generic shounen. I mean this started as ninja and ended with omnipotent super powers. I remember someone talking about how it used to be kunai's and shurikens being thrown but now its nuclear explosion level blasts everywhere. I remember when "ninja" was a term but this is not ninjas anymore this is some DBZ stuff. Another problem is the ending so "SPOLIERS" I guess...... Lets think about children how are they all the same age? Why are the combinations so random? I know Japan has some freaky sexual rituals but I mean how do explain this stuff ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) FILLERS OMG. I was able to endure the 5 episodes but those 5 episodes turned into 30. I dropped the anime at episode 375. Glad I did cause I hear they added a new filler arc right before the final battle lul. Art: 9 It one of the biggest anime all around the world. It would be too much if it didn't have good visuals. Didn't give it a 10/10 cause that Pain vs. Naruto fight was a pain to see ha ha ha..... Sound: 8 Naruto's voice kind of annoys me both in the dub and sub raspy voice. Sakura just annoys me but I attribute that more me no liking her in general. Character: 2 Ok. So Naruto I boy who has attention problems. Yea Yea he lost his parents but he didn't really start caring until he actually "sees" them. Frankly, he put all that attention into ramen jokes. Sasuke the emo crybaby. Let me make up an excuse to hate everything and then contradict myself and make myself look even more stupid. Sakura oh boy. "I love the way you lie" - eminem and rihanna. Sums up Sakura's thoughts I think we all know how that music video ended with (The fire burned everything and everyone). So Sasuke ended up having a child with her after he tried killing her, leaving for 2 years, planning to kill and destroy everything and everyone she loved. Yea oh and after that he then leaves her to be a single mother. Good job kiddo. Oh did I mention she is also useless. Overall: 6 While my review is only pointing out the flaws of this series I have to say I enjoyed my time with the Naruto series in general. Most of it is nostalgia cause Naruto was my gateway into more anime. Naruto is not a perfect anime. You can't give something a 10/10 if it has a flaw. Naruto has many flaws but it doesn't mean I didn't enjoy it. We have to remember to actually set aside the nostalgia. Look at Boruto.. doesn't feel just like a quick cash. In conclusion I liked Naruto but as time went on it didn't hold up. Thanks for reading my review and have a Merry Christmas -Love Santa P.S I don't proof read my reviews I find it cringey so a lot of grammer issues and spelling mitakes will be made. I do proof read my college essays though so don't judge me.

I don't remember the exact last episode I watched, but this show is garbage and everyone should steer clear of it. I watched every episode of Naruto when they aired starting the year the show received an English dub. I stopped during the final arc of the show. I had highly enjoyed the show through much of it and I don't think I'd take those moments back. However, I cannot recommend this show whatsoever to anyone. The studio who made this show MILKED their FANS for money. The manga had been completed at the time the show decided to start running filler in the middle of their final arc. I have spent 7 years watching this show as a loyal fan and I stopped during the final arc. It's because the filler they started doing in the middle of the final arc lasted for over 2.5 years. I waiting 2 years to let episodes build up so my father and I could watch roughly 120 episodes together and binge it hard. There were only 3 canon episodes released within those 2.5 years and the manga had been finished that whole time, meaning the studio was purposely writing 2.5 years of filler to make money from view counts. It's absolutely disgusting. Then to top it all off they made the damn Boruto movie before they even finished the Naruto Shippuuden anime. I am so mad and disappointed. I will never watch another anime from this garbage studio again. Save yourself the trouble and watch a different studio's show. They'll probably care more about their fans and give you an enjoyable show.

Naruto: Shippuden for me, is considered to be an era-defining show; It was something that was culturally influential for the time it was established and arguably STILL is to this day, and has helped shape what anime is generally today. Its by no means a perfect show, and that's what the detail of this review is for. But for what it is, it's something I do recommend people to watch and find themselves to invest their time in when they could. Animation (8/10) - This was a show that ran from 2007 - 2017; Standing the test of time generally, it's animation style is starting to become definitive for its time. It doesn't hurt the viewing experience that much imo, but I do have to say: In comparison to its continuation, Naruto (2002), this one have a noticeably better quality. The movements of the characters are more fluid, and has a more expressive tones onto it. I guess the only criticism I have is Studio Pierrot Co. (its producers), must've started slacking or doing budget cuts at the later parts of its run after The Great War arc concluded because its definition plummeted at around 480-500 episodes deep with some characters lacking details and shading as they used to. But for the majority of its run, I think they did a good job. Storyline (9/10) - Compared to Naruto (2002), this one has a much RICHER storyline. It still bottomlines on the occurrence of The Great War, but all the major arcs that leads slowly onto that progression is seriously action-packed and filled with sensational expositions. A lot of its side characters, especially the antagonists are also well-written in terms of their backstories, purposes and so, that you can't help but appreciate both the spectrum of good and evil as the conflicts unfolds. Also has a lot of blowing and major deaths so, keep your heads up for that. I guess one of the major flaw that I have that kept it from being a 10: Is the excruciating filler episodes and arcs they have. And sometimes they even come along in the MIDDLE of the main arc! As a breather I suppose or to extend their runtime? Idk but it's definitely annoying. Just like Naruto (2002), sometimes it would only be a couple of episodes which can be bearable but there are instances where it could span up to 10-12 eps or something. So it's like a Russian Roulette. And oftentimes those fillers don't even have any direct affect to the main story, so its basically just a waste of time. Definitely the drawback to its perfection. Music (9/10) - Having ten years of total time to simmer on the kitchen, it definitely had a lot of time to cook a lot of bangers and a versatile soundtrack library. It still has its trademark of Traditional Japanese-like thematic mostly on its background music that implements a rich flavor of woodwind, strings and percussion harmonies. But in terms of OSTs, it invested a lot on Japanese Rock which they did very well because a lot of the famous songs associated with the show came from this type of genre. Most notably Blue Bird, Silhouette, Sign and more, typically relying on fast-paced guitar riffs, crashing drums and snares, raw and energetic vocals into a singularity of a melody; The type of thing that would make your head bang and get drawn onto the tunes. Very lit, if you'd ask me. So props to that. Overall - 8.66 out of 10

Throughout the first part and all of Shippuden, I had to endure the stupid MC and disgusting personality Sakura, which is definitely a downside. But I started watching Naruto as a kid, so it would have been a shame not to check it out. I mostly watched it for characters like Kakashi, Madara, and Sai, because these characters are really interesting, use their brains, and have something to convey, unlike the two mentioned characters. Generally, the world and story are interesting. If Naruto came out now, I wouldn't watch it because of too many useless episodes, but I watched it because of nostalgia. 9/10, and of course, because of Madara, who remains one of the best "villains" in anime.I put the word 'villain' in quotation marks because his goal is the dream of every mature person a dystopia where people would be much happier than in the presented world

Naruto is my favorite anime of all time. I've been following it since 2010 and since then, I've watched many animes. Still, nothing compares to it. Attack on Titan may come as second, but it's no way near it. The theme is just too brilliant. It's something that never ever came into my mind. I really like the world of ninjas depicted in this show. I like the idea of Jutsu and Chakra. I love the fights. I love the backstories of each character. The characters' development is incredibly consistent. The show will fill you with many emotions: inspiring, charming, funny, sad, etc. The arcs and fights will blow your mind: it's strategic, a trait that many others lack; it's wholesome, not just punching around like a sh*t or throwing random powers like Dragon Ball and One Piece. I have too many favorite fights and arcs that make it impossible to list here, but the best one is certainly The Pain Invasion. That being said, sadly this amazing show has to suffer from many of what I call "anime's fallacies". They are defects that lower the anime's potential. These didn't happen very often, tho, gladly. But, I'm a very logical person, and I love to have a show to be logical if it's meant to be. - The main characters shall not be dead because we'll lose many fans / we cannot make up their subsequent story. - Forget about side characters, just let them be punching bags. - Mouthful during fights. The characters bother explaining his plot after defeating his opponent (they did this so that the viewer can also understand, but it's nonsense. It should be explained with flashback). - Show the greatness of the villain by nerfing (making weak) the good characters. - The level of power has to increase dramatically over time (you know, in the Naruto series, kunai and shuriken were still a weapon to kill enemies. In Shippuden, they were just an adornment). The first fallacy makes many illogical events happen. (spoiler alert! skip this paragraph if you haven't watched yet). Because of the author's insistence on keeping the main characters alive, Gaara and Kakashi had to be revived by some weird Jutsu. Choji and Ino didn't die after being suffocated by Kakuzu. Sasuke didn't die after being stabbed by Madara on his heart. All five kages didn't die after being knocked down by Madara. C'mon, have the courage to kill them. Did Death Note lose his fanbase after killing L, its favorite character? Did AOT lose after killing Sasha and Captain Erwin? The last fallacy is what I dislike most. It went from Zabuza's level -> Pain's level -> Madara's level -> Kaguya's level. In the last arc, they were just fighting against aliens and throwing a bunch of unknown jutsus, making the show like Dragon Ball which really undermined strategy. I have no idea why Kishi had this in mind. I hope it stopped at Madara's level where the fights were still consumable. All in all, I don't find any anime without defects. If Kishi had the second chance to remake this show, I think it'll become unequivocally the greatest anime ever.

This anime is by far my favorite, and I don't think there'll be anything that will surpass it. Though, I will admit it isn't overall perfect, but what anime is. All that matters that in my eyes I believe it to be the best and that's my opinion. Story- 9/10 The story in Shippuden, while not extremely complex like some anime, it still contains underlying tones and messages in its arcs that make you think. It starts off immediately into an entertaining arc that once it starts the series never looks back. There wasn't an arc that I can say I didn't enjoy (excluding filler), some are even my favorite arcs in all of anime, and while they mainly dealt with Naruto and Sasuke, the arcs also gave other characters development and growth that you don't see in a lot of series. The results of each arc are felt and have lasting effects on the characters and me as a viewer. Some arcs made me cry, some cheer, and some even caused me to reflect on life. Character deaths are meaningful and aren't something that are just brushed past, they are talked about and impact the series the rest of the show. The world is expanded upon and so is the lore that makes a somewhat smaller world larger and enhances it in the process. Art- 8.5/10 The animation in this show is its weakest point, but I wouldn't call it a negative. There are moments where you can see the flaws in certain scenes, where characters are making weird faces. Other than that the animation is good and the fight scenes are very well done with the visuals looking extremely good and the characters animated well. The fight scenes especially are amazing, with the attacks looking great, and the choreography of the fights can be among the best. Sound- 10/10 The ost for Shippuden is among the best with emotional scenes being enhances by the background music, the fights feeling more intense because of it, and the comedic scenes better. So, the soundtrack does what it's supposed to do, enhances the overall anime. It is also, so good that I listen to a lot of them in my free time outside of watching the anime. Characters- 10/10 Now we are on the strongest point of Shippuden, the cast of characters. Naruto and Sasuke are my favorite characters in anime, along with a couple of the supporting characters being in my top 20. Naruto and Sasuke are very well layered characters that change with what they experience around them, making them feel very human. Their bond is also something to love because they are the best pair of characters in anime, with how they interact with each other. Then, there's the supporting cast like; Kakashi, Shikamaru, Might Guy, Jiraiya, etc. Most get developed, some more than others, but it helps make you care more about these characters and what they go through in the story. Lastly there's the villains, which are also extremely strong characters, who have their own backstories and reasons for what they do. It makes you understand them, sympathize with them, and even agree with some of the points that they make. So, overall the characters are one of the major reasons that I enjoyed Shippuden. Enjoyment- 10/10 If you couldn't tell based off of what I wrote before this, I enjoy Shippuden to the fullest degree. Enough that I re-watched it twice and still got the same enjoyment out of it that I had the first time I watched it. Overall- 10/10 So, overall I think that this is the best anime out there. Obviously this is my opinion and everyone has a right to their own. However, I request that you give it a chance if you haven't already, and I hope you get the same enjoyment out of it as I did.

I love the Naruto franchise... and Shippuden Just solidified that fact for me!!! Naruto is a challenging exploration of themes such as the cycle of hatred, war, comradery, and peace. Through its expressive and varied cast of characters, it paints a vivid picture of the world in which they inhabit. This rich world is further brought to life by the gorgeous sound design and visuals. Shippuden truly is a sensory treat. And I haven't even started on the characters. Kishimoto works best in creating memorable and fresh character dynamics that keep you drawn to the screen. In particular the dynamic between Naruto and Pain is a masterclass in storytelling, not only being highly enjoyable, but also deeply tying into the show's themes... ...is what I would say if I were a CHUMP! Naruto sux!! Haha just kidding, I meant what I said. Got you there kind moderator 😂 Thank you for reading my review. Glopglup, signing off...

I will keep this short: Manga 10/10 Games 10/10 (they are much better then even manga) Anime 4/10 Once again the filler percentage is around 41% with ethe same problems as the Naruto Part 1 anime. Fillers don't give us nothing new to overall story, and exist only to overstretch the anime livespan. When anime adapts the story from the manga it's really perfect, but when the filler arrives it simply downgrades.I did even put a higher score because this show started to adapt some of light novels, but if you're watching this anime weekly it was impossible to tell the difference back then. For the manga it's really a shonen classic at this point of time. The Storm games did even surpass the manga with the showcase of the final bosses fights (Naruto Shippuden opening 8 reference is the best example).
